channel.title: NJ Supreme Court Oral Arguments
channel.description: Oral argument mp3s from the NJ States Supreme Court

item.title: State v. Eddie L. Oliver
item.description: Does a trial court have discretion to deny an inmate’s petition for compassionate release if the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the inmate “is so debilitated or incapacitated by the terminal condition, disease or syndrome, or permanent physical incapacity as to be permanently physically incapable of committing a crime if released and, in the case of a permanent physical incapacity,” the inmate “would not pose a threat to public safety,” under N.J.S.A. 30:4-123.51e(f)(1)?

item.title: State v. A.M.
item.description: Does a trial court have discretion to deny an inmate’s petition for compassionate release if the court finds, by clear and convincing evidence, that the inmate “is so debilitated or incapacitated by the terminal condition, disease or syndrome, or permanent physical incapacity as to be permanently physically incapable of committing a crime if released and, in the case of a permanent physical incapacity,” the inmate “would not pose a threat to public safety,” under N.J.S.A. 30:4-123.51e(f)(1)?

item.title: Liberty Insurance Corp. v. Techdan, LLC
item.description: In this insurance fraud litigation, does the Comparative Negligence Act apply and should the jury instructions have included the ultimate outcome charge?

item.title: Liberty Insurance Corp. v. Techdan, LLC
item.description: In this insurance fraud litigation, does the Comparative Negligence Act apply and should the jury instructions have included the ultimate outcome charge?

item.title: Harold Hansen v. Rite Aid Corp.
item.description: When a trial court awards attorney’s fees to a prevailing party under a statutory fee-shifting provision, may it award fees for prior appellate work in the matter if the party did not file a counsel fee motion with the appellate court?

item.title: Harold Hansen v. Rite Aid Corp.
item.description: When a trial court awards attorney’s fees to a prevailing party under a statutory fee-shifting provision, may it award fees for prior appellate work in the matter if the party did not file a counsel fee motion with the appellate court?

item.title: In the Matter of Proposed Construction of Compressor Station (CS327)
item.description: In this matter concerning plans for the construction of a compressor station in the Highlands preservation area, should a company that was granted an exemption from the provisions and regulations of the Highlands Water Protection and Planning Act by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection be allowed to intervene in an appeal of that agency decision?

item.title: State v. Marcus Mackroy-Davis
item.description: Did the trial court abuse its discretion by designating particular periods of excludable time for purposes of calculating the speedy trial deadlines under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:162-15 to -26?

item.title: State Of New Jersey In The Interest Of E.S.
item.description: In this juvenile proceeding, where the juvenile moved to suppress evidence and the State moved for waiver of the matter to the Law Division, did the Family Part judge abuse his discretion in determining to proceed with the waiver hearing before the suppression motion?

item.title: Green Knight Capital, LLC v. Gabriel Calderon
item.description: Was permitting a third party to attempt redemption of the tax sale certificate after plaintiff had filed a foreclosure complaint consistent with N.J.S.A. 54:5-98 and Simon v. Cronecker, 189 N.J. 304 (2007)?

item.title: Nancy L. Holm v. Daniel M. Purdy
item.description: Does the Workers’ Compensation Act, N.J.S.A. 34:15-36, impose a legal duty on an insurance broker to advise new members of an LLC of the need to opt-in for worker’s compensation coverage?

item.title: State v. Woodrow Miller
item.description: In this proceeding for post-conviction relief, did defendant show that he received ineffective assistance of trial counsel entitling him to a new trial?

item.title: State v. Quinnizel J. Clark
item.description: Did the admission of evidence that defendant asked for a lawyer when the interrogating officer asked him to exculpate himself, and the prosecutor’s comments during summations, violate defendant’s Fifth Amendment right to counsel?

item.title: Morgan Dennehy v. East Windsor Regional Board of Education
item.description: When an injured high-school athlete asserts a claim alleging that the negligence of the team coach was the cause of her injury, is the claim against the coach subject to the heightened recklessness standard of care that applies to participants in recreational sporting activities under Crawn v. Campo, 136 N.J. 494 (1994)?

item.title: State v. Terrell M. Chambers
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, can the State be compelled to obtain and produce an alleged sexual assault victim’s mental health records for an in camera review by the trial court?

item.title: In the Matter of Officer Gregory DiGuglielmo and New Jersey Institute of Technology
item.description: Is a campus police officer at a public college or university eligible for special disciplinary arbitration administered by the Public Employment Relations Commission?

item.title: State v. Steven L. Bookman
item.description: When police officers attempt to execute an Automated Traffic System warrant and the subject flees, is it permissible for officers to enter a third party’s home under the hot pursuit doctrine?

item.title: State v. Jamal Wade
item.description: Did defendant, who contends he was not informed of the nature of the charges against him or that he was under arrest, knowingly and voluntarily waive his Miranda rights?

item.title: Linden Democratic Committee v. City of Linden
item.description: Under the Municipal Vacancy Law, N.J.S.A. 40A:16-1 to -23, did the Linden Municipal Council have discretion to keep a seat on the Council vacant until the next general election, rather than appointing one of the three nominees presented by the Linden Democratic Committee to fill the vacant seat?

item.title: Mirian Rivera v. The Valley Hospital, Inc.
item.description: In this medical malpractice action, were defendants entitled to partial summary judgment on plaintiffs’ claims for punitive damages?

item.title: Norman International, Inc. v. Admiral Insurance Company
item.description: Does the "Designated New York Counties Exclusion" in the insurance policy, which excludes coverage for injuries "arising out of, related to, caused by, contributed to by, or in any way connected with" any operations or activities in, as relevant here, Nassau County, New York, apply under the circumstances?

item.title: Dobco, Inc v. Bergen County Improvement Authority
item.description: Can a principal of a corporate entity challenge a procurement process if the corporate entity is barred from doing so, and when a county improvement authority is designated as the redevelopment entity under the Local Redevelopment and Housing Law, do the public bidding requirements of the Local Public Contracts Law apply to the county improvement authority’s selection of a redeveloper to serve as general contractor?

item.title: Dobco, Inc v. Bergen County Improvement Authority
item.description: Can a principal of a corporate entity challenge a procurement process if the corporate entity is barred from doing so, and when a county improvement authority is designated as the redevelopment entity under the Local Redevelopment and Housing Law, do the public bidding requirements of the Local Public Contracts Law apply to the county improvement authority’s selection of a redeveloper to serve as general contractor?

item.title: Ann Samolyk v. Dorothy Berthe, III
item.description: Does the rescue doctrine, which in some instances permits an injured rescuer to maintain a cause of action against the person whose negligence placed a victim in imminent danger, extend to the rescue of a dog?

item.title: State v. Rahee Lane
item.description: Does mitigating factor fourteen, N.J.S.A. 2C:44-1(b)(14), that the "defendant was under 26 years of age at the time of the commission of the offense," apply retroactively?

item.title: State v. Rahee Lane
item.description: Does mitigating factor fourteen, N.J.S.A. 2C:44-1(b)(14), that the "defendant was under 26 years of age at the time of the commission of the offense," apply retroactively?

item.title: State v. Abayuba Rivas
item.description: Did the suppression of defendant’s statement to police for the violation of his right to counsel require the suppression of defendant’s later statements to police, which were made the following day?

item.title: State v. Mykal L. Derry; State v. Malik Derry
item.description: Should defendants’ motions to dismiss the indictment under N.J.S.A. 2C:1-3(f) and or N.J.S.A. 2C:1-11 have been granted because they were sentenced to life in prison in a related federal case and was the admission of testimony defining slang terminology without the witness being qualified as an expert harmless error?

item.title: State v. F.E.D.
item.description: Was defendant eligible for compassionate release under N.J.S.A. 30:4-123.51e?

item.title: State v. F.E.D.
item.description: Was defendant eligible for compassionate release under N.J.S.A. 30:4-123.51e?

item.title: Mack-Cali Realty Corp. v. State of New Jersey
item.description: Did the "residency exemption" in Jersey City’s payroll tax violate the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution?

item.title: East Bay Drywall, LLC v. Department of Labor and Workforce Development
item.description: For purposes of liability for contributions to the state unemployment and temporary disability compensation fund, are the company’s service providers employees or independent contractors under the ABC Test, N.J.S.A. 43:21-19(i)(6)(A) to (C)?

item.title: East Bay Drywall, LLC v. Department of Labor and Workforce Development
item.description: For purposes of liability for contributions to the state unemployment and temporary disability compensation fund, are the company’s service providers employees or independent contractors under the ABC Test, N.J.S.A. 43:21-19(i)(6)(A) to (C)?

item.title: State v. William J. Kane
item.description: Did the detectives have reasonable articulable suspicion to stop defendant?

item.title: Thomasenia L. Fowler v. Akzo Nobel Chemicals, Inc.
item.description: In this action concerning decedent’s mesothelioma, were the jury instructions on defendant’s duty to warn and on medical causation erroneous, requiring reversal of the jury’s verdict in favor of plaintiff?

item.title: State v. David L. Smith
item.description: Did the detectives have reasonable articulable suspicion of a motor vehicle offense, namely that defendant’s tinted windows violated the motor vehicle code?

item.title: State v. A.L.A.
item.description: Was the court required to tailor the jury instructions for simple assault to explain that not all corporal punishment is simple assault?

item.title: Aleice Jeter v. Sam’s Club
item.description: Does the mode-of-operation rule apply to defendant’s sale of grapes?

item.title: State v. Oscar Ramirez
item.description: Is defense counsel entitled to the victim’s home address as part of discovery in this criminal prosecution?

item.title: State v. O.D.A.-C.
item.description: Should defendant’s statement have been suppressed because the detective’s comments while questioning defendant vitiated his rights under Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966)?

item.title: State v. Nazier D. Goldsmith
item.description: Did the police officers have a reasonable and articulable suspicion to stop defendant and to frisk him?

item.title: Crystal Point Condominium Association, Inc. v. Kinsale Insurance Company
item.description: Does the direct action statute, N.J.S.A. 17:28-2, apply, and is plaintiff bound by the mandatory arbitration provision in the underlying insurance contract?

item.title: Crystal Point Condominium Association, Inc. v. Kinsale Insurance Company
item.description: Does the direct action statute, N.J.S.A. 17:28-2, apply, and is plaintiff bound by the mandatory arbitration provision in the underlying insurance contract?

item.title: State v. Rashaun Bell
item.description: If a single accident results in more than one death, does the rule of multiplicity prohibit charging a defendant for multiple counts of leaving the scene of an accident resulting in the death of another person, N.J.S.A. 2C:11-5.1?

item.title: State v. Rashaun Bell
item.description: If a single accident results in more than one death, does the rule of multiplicity prohibit charging a defendant for multiple counts of leaving the scene of an accident resulting in the death of another person, N.J.S.A. 2C:11-5.1?

item.title: Robert Sipko v. Koger, Inc.
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, is a remand required to reconsider the valuation of Koger Distributed Solutions, Inc., and Koger Professional Services, Inc.?

item.title: Sundiata Acoli v. New Jersey State Parole Board
item.description: Was the parole board’s determination that there was a substantial likelihood that Sundiata Acoli would commit a crime if released on parole arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable?

item.title: Sundiata Acoli v. New Jersey State Parole Board
item.description: Was the parole board’s determination that there was a substantial likelihood that Sundiata Acoli would commit a crime if released on parole arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable?

item.title: State v. William A. Gerena
item.description: Was the testimony from a police officer and a lay witness estimating the heights and ages of children that they observed near defendant in a public park admissible in this criminal trial in which defendant was charged with offenses that include as a statutory element that one of the children be under the age of thirteen?

item.title: Graphnet, Inc. v. Retarus, Inc.
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, is plaintiff entitled to a new trial on nominal damages?

item.title: Troy Haviland v. Lourdes Medical Center of Burlington County, Inc.
item.description: Does the Affidavit of Merit Statute, N.J.S.A. 2A:53A-26 to -29, require an affidavit of merit when a plaintiff’s sole claim against a health care facility is vicarious liability based on the alleged medical negligence of an employee against whom no affidavit of merit is required?

item.title: Diane S. Lapsley v. Township of Sparta
item.description: Were petitioner’s injuries, which resulted when she was struck by a snowplow driven by a Township employee as she was walking after work in a parking lot used by Township employees, compensable pursuant to the Workers’ Compensation Act, particularly under the premises rule, N.J.S.A. 34:15-36?

item.title: State v. Quinnizel J. Clark
item.description: Did the cumulative effect of errors deprive defendant of a fair trial?

item.title: Horizon Blue Cross Blue Shield of New Jersey v. Speech & Language Center, LLC
item.description: Is the clause in the settlement agreement, which provides that settlement payments are non-dischargeable in bankruptcy, void as against public policy in New Jersey?

item.title: State v. Samuel Ryan
item.description: Can an offense committed as a juvenile serve as a predicate offense for imposition of a sentence of life without parole under N.J.S.A. 2C:43-7.1(a), known as the “Three Strikes Law”?

item.title: Kathleen M. Moynihan v. Edward J. Lynch
item.description: Among other issues in this palimony action, is the written agreement between the parties unenforceable due to the 2010 amendment to the Statute of Frauds, N.J.S.A. 25:1-5(h)?

item.title: Kathleen M. Moynihan v. Edward J. Lynch
item.description: Among other issues in this palimony action, is the written agreement between the parties unenforceable due to the 2010 amendment to the Statute of Frauds, N.J.S.A. 25:1-5(h)?

item.title: Thomas J. Stewart v. New Jersey Turnpike Authority/Garden State Parkway
item.description: Did plaintiffs establish the requisite elements to impose liability against a public entity and its general contractor under the Tort Claims Act?

item.title: State v. Ashley D. Bailey
item.description: Were the text messages exchanged between defendant and her spouse admissible under the crime-fraud exception to the marital privilege, N.J.R.E. 509(2)(e), when those text messages were exchanged prior to adoption of the crime-fraud exception?

item.title: Hamid Harris v. City of Newark
item.description: Is a trial court order denying qualified immunity under the New Jersey Civil Rights Act, N.J.S.A. 10:6-2, immediately appealable to the Appellate Division as of right, notwithstanding the absence of a final judgment?

item.title: Richard Rivera v. Union County Prosecutor’s Office
item.description: Are the police department internal affairs reports at issue subject to disclosure under the Open Public Records Act and the common law right of access?

item.title: John C. Sullivan v. Max Spann Real Estate & Auction Co.
item.description: Do real estate auction sales contracts prepared by attorneys, licensed real estate brokers, or salespersons need to contain the three-day attorney review clause mandated by N.J. State Bar Ass’n v. N.J. Ass’n of Realtor Boards, 93 N.J. 470 (1983), when a blank, pre-printed contract is sent to the bidder prior to the auction of a single family home and recommends that an attorney review the contract?

item.title: State v. Wildemar A. Dangcil
item.description: Is the hybrid-virtual jury selection procedure adopted in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, under which certain aspects of the jury selection process are conducted remotely, constitutionally sound?

item.title: Larry Schwartz v. Nicholas Menas, Esq.
item.description: Does the new business rule, which bars damages for the prospective profits of a new business, bar plaintiff’s experts’ reports estimating lost-profit damages from development projects that plaintiffs alleged were thwarted by defendants?

item.title: State v. Anthony Sims, Jr.
item.description: Were the officers required to advise defendant, who was not charged with any offenses at the time, why he was arrested before proceeding with the custodial interrogation, and was the victim’s out-of-court identification of defendant admissible where the victim did not testify at trial?

item.title: State v. Anthony Sims, Jr.
item.description: Were the officers required to advise defendant, who was not charged with any offenses at the time, why he was arrested before proceeding with the custodial interrogation, and was the victim’s out-of-court identification of defendant admissible where the victim did not testify at trial?

item.title: Michele Meade v. Township of Livingston
item.description: In this action alleging wrongful termination based on gender discrimination in violation of the New Jersey Law Against Discrimination, was plaintiff’s claim sufficient to survive summary judgment?

item.title: Todd B. Glassman v. Steven P. Friedel, M.D.
item.description: Does the framework established in Ciluffo v. Middlesex General Hospital, 146 N.J. Super. 476 (App. Div. 1977), which awards a pro tanto credit to successive tortfeasors in medical malpractice cases if the plaintiff settles with the first tortfeasor, remain valid after enactment of the Comparative Negligence Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:15-5.1 to -5.8?

item.title: State v. Laura Gonzalez
item.description: Did defendant invoke her right to counsel such that her oral and written statements should have been suppressed and was certain testimony at trial opinion evidence on the ultimate issue of proof of child abuse that invaded the province of the jury?

item.title: Cooper Hospital University Medical Center v. Selective Insurance Company of America
item.description: Does Medicare or a private insurance carrier have primary payment responsibility for hospital services for ongoing medical injuries arising out of an accident that occurred prior to enactment of the Medicare Second Payer Statute (MSP), 42 U.S.C. § 1395y(b)?

item.title: Cooper Hospital University Medical Center v. Selective Insurance Company of America
item.description: Does Medicare or a private insurance carrier have primary payment responsibility for hospital services for ongoing medical injuries arising out of an accident that occurred prior to enactment of the Medicare Second Payer Statute (MSP), 42 U.S.C. § 1395y(b)?

item.title: State v. Keith Terres
item.description: Was it permissible for the police officers to conduct of a protective sweep of defendant’s residence when an individual was arrested on the front porch?

item.title: State v. Christopher Radel
item.description: Was it permissible for the police officers to conduct of a protective sweep of defendant’s residence when he was arrested in his driveway outside the residence?

item.title: State v. James C. Zarate
item.description: Did the sentencing court appropriately consider defendant’s youth and was the sentence permissible given that the court did not find that defendant was permanently incorrigible?

item.title: State v. James Comer
item.description: Is N.J.S.A. 2C:11-3(b)(1), which mandates a minimum sentence of at least thirty years in prison without parole for murder, unconstitutional as applied to juvenile offenders?

item.title: State v. Bradley C. Thompson
item.description: When does the statute of limitations for a criminal offense begin to run under N.J.S.A. 2C:1-6(c) when DNA testing is used to identify the defendant?

item.title: State v. Bradley C. Thompson
item.description: When does the statute of limitations for a criminal offense begin to run under N.J.S.A. 2C:1-6(c) when DNA testing is used to identify the defendant?

item.title: State v. Jamar J. Myers
item.description: Did the officer have a reasonable articulable suspicion to stop the car in which defendant was a passenger?

item.title: State v. Peter Nyema
item.description: Did the officer have a reasonable articulable suspicion to stop the car in which defendant was a passenger?

item.title: G.C. v. Division of Medical Assistance and Health Services
item.description: Does N.J.A.C. 10:72-4.4(d)(1), which renders an applicant ineligible for medical assistance benefits under the NJ Medicaid Aged, Blind, Disabled Program if the applicant’s countable income “exceeds the poverty income guideline for one person,” conflict with the New Jersey Medical Assistance and Health Services Act, N.J.S.A. 30:4D-3(i)(11), or the federal Medicaid statute, 42 U.S.C. § 1396(m)(2)(A)?

item.title: G.C. v. Division of Medical Assistance and Health Services
item.description: Does N.J.A.C. 10:72-4.4(d)(1), which renders an applicant ineligible for medical assistance benefits under the NJ Medicaid Aged, Blind, Disabled Program if the applicant’s countable income “exceeds the poverty income guideline for one person,” conflict with the New Jersey Medical Assistance and Health Services Act, N.J.S.A. 30:4D-3(i)(11), or the federal Medicaid statute, 42 U.S.C. § 1396(m)(2)(A)?

item.title: Libertarians for Transparent Government v. Cumberland County
item.description: Is a settlement agreement between a county government and a former employee resolving an internal disciplinary action against the employee a government record under section 10 of the Open Public Records Act, N.J.S.A. 47:1A-10?

item.title: State v. Omar Vega-Larregui
item.description: Should the indictment against defendant be dismissed on constitutional grounds, specifically on the basis that it was returned by a Grand Jury proceeding conducted remotely, pursuant to the Virtual Grand Jury Program adopted in response to the COVID-19 pandemic?

item.title: In the Matter of the Request to Release Certain Pretrial Detainees
item.description: Through this application, the Court considers a request by the Office of the Public Defender and the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey that seeks relief relating to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the suspension of in-person criminal jury trials on defendants who have been detained pretrial. Specifically, the applicants seek: (1) the release of all defendants detained for six months or longer whose most serious charge is a second-degree offense or lower, with an opportunity for the State to object in individual cases and seek to justify continued detention under an enhanced burden of proof; and (2) new detention hearings for all defendants detained for six months or longer who are charged with a first-degree offense and entitled to a presumption of release.

item.title: Brenda Gilbert v. Kenyatta K. Stewart, Esq.
item.description: In this legal malpractice action, was defendant entitled to summary judgment on the grounds that his breach of the duty of care owed to plaintiff was not the proximate cause of her damages?

item.title: In re Attorney General Law Enforcement Directive Nos. 2020-05 and 2020-06
item.description: Among other challenges to the adoption of these Directives, does the Attorney General have the authority to require public disclosure of the names of police officers assessed “major discipline”?

item.title: In re Attorney General Law Enforcement Directive Nos. 2020-05 and 2020-06
item.description: Among other challenges to the adoption of these Directives, does the Attorney General have the authority to require public disclosure of the names of police officers assessed “major discipline”?

item.title: State v. David Chavies
item.description: Did defendant satisfy the medical predicates for relief under Rule 3:21-10(b)(2), and is a defendant barred from release under Rule 3:21-10(b)(2) while serving a mandatory period of parole ineligibility?

item.title: In the Matter of Registrant J.D.-F.
item.description: Does N.J.S.A. 2C:7-2(g) apply to a defendant who committed an offense before the statute’s enactment but was sentenced afterwards?

item.title: Armando Rios, Jr. v. Meda Pharmaceutical, Inc.
item.description: In this action in which plaintiff asserted that his supervisor’s use of racial slurs on two occasions created a hostile work environment in violation of the New Jersey Law Against Discrimination, were there material issues of fact that precluded the grant of summary judgment to defendants?

item.title: State v. Tywaun S. Hedgespeth
item.description: Was it harmless error for the trial court to determine that defendant’s prior convictions could be used to impeach him under N.J.R.E. 609 where that determination resulted in defendant’s decision not to testify, and did the admission of an affidavit certifying the nonexistence of a gun permit without testimony by the affiant violate the Confrontation Clause?

item.title: State v. Michael Konecny
item.description: Can a defendant’s past uncounseled convictions for driving while intoxicated (DWI) support a conviction under N.J.S.A. 2C:40-26(b), which prohibits driving during a period of license suspension imposed following a second or subsequent conviction for DWI?

item.title: State v. Laquan Harris
item.description: In this post-conviction relief proceeding, did defendant show that he received ineffective assistance of trial counsel entitling him to a new trial?

item.title: Estate of Hiram A. Gonzalez v. The City of Jersey City
item.description: Were the actions of the police officers ministerial in nature such that they were not immune from liability under the Tort Claims Act?

item.title: Estate of Hiram A. Gonzalez v. The City of Jersey City
item.description: Were the actions of the police officers ministerial in nature such that they were not immune from liability under the Tort Claims Act?

item.title: Baffi Simmons v. Wendy Mercado
item.description: Are complaints and summonses in the State’s Electronic Complaint Disposition Record (ECDR) system subject to production under the Open Public Records Act?

item.title: Bonay Goldhagen v. Susan Pasmowitz
item.description: Does the strict liability dog bite statute, N.J.S.A. 4:19-16, have an assumption of the risk exception for independent contractors?

item.title: State v. Bennie Anderson
item.description: Was the forfeiture of this public employee’s pension a fine that implicates the Excessive Fines Clause of the Eighth Amendment to the United States Constitution and Article I, Paragraph 12 of the New Jersey Constitution, and if so, what factors should courts consider when assessing whether pension forfeiture is excessive?

item.title: State v. Jose Carrion
item.description: Did the failure of the arresting officers to apprise defendant of his Miranda rights prior to his initial statements in his apartment preclude the admission of his subsequent warned statements at the police station; and did the admission of an affidavit certifying the nonexistence of a gun permit without testimony by the affiant violate the Confrontation Clause?

item.title: State v. Michelle Paden-Battle
item.description: Did the jury’s verdict acquitting defendant of murder, conspiracy to commit murder, and weapons offenses preclude the sentencing court from finding that defendant ordered the victim’s execution?

item.title: Ernest Bozzi v. City of Jersey City
item.description: Under the Open Public Records Act, was plaintiff entitled to the names and addresses of individuals possessing a dog license issued by Jersey City?

item.title: State v. Rasheem W. McQueen and Myshira T. Allen-Brewer
item.description: Did the State’s acquisition of the recording of a telephone call placed from the police station’s phone violate the Fourth Amendment?

item.title: Borough of Carteret v. Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association, Local 67
item.description: Was the arbitrator’s interpretation of the disputed clause in the parties’ collective negotiations agreement reasonably debatable?

item.title: Borough of Carteret v. Firefighters Mutual Benevolent Association, Local 67
item.description: Was the arbitrator’s interpretation of the disputed clause in the parties’ collective negotiations agreement reasonably debatable?

item.title: State v. Juan C. Molchor; State v. Jose A. Rios
item.description: Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:162-15 to -26, can a defendant’s immigration status form the basis for the court’s pretrial detention decision?

item.title: State v. Juan C. Molchor; State v. Jose A. Rios
item.description: Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:162-15 to -26, can a defendant’s immigration status form the basis for the court’s pretrial detention decision?

item.title: State v. Oscar Lopez-Carrera
item.description: Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:162-15 to -26, can a court consider the issuance of a Final Removal Order when deciding whether to detain the defendant?

item.title: State v. Oscar Lopez-Carrera
item.description: Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, N.J.S.A. 2A:162-15 to -26, can a court consider the issuance of a Final Removal Order when deciding whether to detain the defendant?

item.title: State v. Cynthia Rivera
item.description: Was the sentencing court’s finding and weighing of the aggravating and mitigating factors based on sufficient, credible evidence in the record and did the court adequately explain its reasoning?

item.title: State v. Edwin Andujar
item.description: Was defendant’s conviction properly reversed where the State ran a criminal background check on a minority member of the jury pool after it unsuccessfully sought to remove the prospective juror for cause?

item.title: State v. Edwin Andujar
item.description: Was defendant’s conviction properly reversed where the State ran a criminal background check on a minority member of the jury pool after it unsuccessfully sought to remove the prospective juror for cause?

item.title: Shelley Pritchett v. State of New Jersey
item.description: Was the punitive damages award against a public entity reasonable and proportional?

item.title: Angel Alberto Pareja v. Princeton International Properties
item.description: Does a commercial landowner have a duty to take reasonable steps to render a public walkway abutting its property—covered by snow or ice—reasonably safe, while precipitation is falling?

item.title: Leah Coleman v. Sonia Martinez
item.description: Was it foreseeable that defendant’s client would commit an act of violence against plaintiff, such that defendant had a duty to take reasonable steps to avoid exposing plaintiff to danger posed by the client?

item.title: H.C. Equities, LP v. County of Union
item.description: Were the letters that plaintiff sent timely under the New Jersey Tort Claims Act, N.J.S.A. 59:8-8, and did they substantially comply with the notice requirements of the Act?

item.title: New Jersey Republican State Committee v. Philip D. Murphy
item.description: In this matter, the Supreme Court considers a constitutional challenge to the New Jersey COVID-19 Emergency Bond Act, which authorizes the issuance of up to $9.9 billion in State general obligation bonds to be used for the purpose of responding to the fiscal exigencies caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: The Bank of New York Mellon v. Marianne Corradetti
item.description: Among other issues, did the evidence at trial establish that defendants’ signatures on the mortgage documents were forgeries?

item.title: State v. Leo T. Little, Jr.
item.description: In this case in which defendant was charged with weapons offenses, was it reversible error for the judge to ask potential jurors during voir dire whether it would affect their ability to be fair and impartial if the State did not produce a gun, and for the prosecutor to dismiss jurors based on their answers to that question?

item.title: State v. Paulino Njango
item.description: Where a person was wrongfully imprisoned beyond the term of incarceration, can prior service credits be applied to reduce the mandatory period of parole supervision under the No Early Release Act, N.J.S.A. 2C:43-7.2?

item.title: Tyrone A. Huggins v. Mary E. Aquilar
item.description: Is the provision in the automobile dealer’s insurance policy, which provides coverage in the minimum amount required by law only if the driver of the vehicle has no other coverage or if the driver has coverage in an amount less than the statutory minimum, a permissible step-down provision or an unlawful escape clause?

item.title: Ellen Baskin v. P.C. Richard & Son, LLC
item.description: Did plaintiffs meet the requirements for class certification under Rule 4:32-1, including numerosity, superiority, and predominance?

item.title: J.K. v. New Jersey State Parole Board
item.description: Among other issues, was the parole board’s denial of J.K.’s application to reside in another country, which approval was required because he was subject community supervision for life under Megan’s Law, arbitrary, capricious, or unreasonable?

item.title: State v. Wilbert Hannah

item.title: New Jersey Transit Corporation v. Certain Underwriters at Lloyd’s London

item.title: State v. Craig Szemple

item.title: Kathleen J. Delanoy v. Township of Ocean

item.title: State v. Miguel A. Roman-Rosado
item.description: Among other issues, did the police officer have reasonable suspicion to effectuate a traffic stop under N.J.S.A. 39:3-33, which prohibits “a license plate frame or identification marker holder that conceals or otherwise obscures any part of any marking imprinted upon the vehicle’s” license plate?

item.title: State v. Darius J. Carter
item.description: Did the police officer have reasonable suspicion to effectuate a traffic stop under N.J.S.A. 39:3-33, which prohibits “a license plate frame or identification marker holder that conceals or otherwise obscures any part of any marking imprinted upon the vehicle’s” license plate?

item.title: Vincent Hager v. M&K Construction
item.description: Among other issues, may a workers’ compensation judge order an employer to reimburse its employee for the cost of the employee’s medical marijuana prescribed for chronic pain following a work-related accident?

item.title: In the Matter of the Civil Commitment of W.W., SVP-86-00
item.description: Does N.J.S.A. 30:4-27.30(b) require the State to present testimony from a psychiatrist in support of the involuntary commitment of a sexually violent predator?

item.title: In the Matter of the Request to Modify Prison Sentences, Expedite Parole Hearings, and Identify Vulnerable Prisoners
item.description: Through this application, the Court considers a request by the Office of the Public Defender and the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey seeking relief relating to the spread of COVID-19 in state prison and juvenile facilities. Specifically, the applicants sought a framework under which judges or court-appointed special masters would decide whether to grant release or a furlough in individual cases after considering any objections for the early release of several groups of inmates: adults and juveniles serving a sentence that will expire in the next year; individuals eligible for parole; and any defendant who is particularly vulnerable to COVID-19.

item.title: In re Opinion No. 735 of the Supreme Court Advisory Committee on Professional Ethics
item.description: May an attorney, consistent with the Rules of Professional Conduct, purchase from an internet search engine company a keyword that is a competitor lawyer’s name in order to display the purchasing lawyer’s own website in the search results when a person searches for the competitor lawyer by name?

item.title: In re Opinion No. 735 of the Supreme Court Advisory Committee on Professional Ethics
item.description: May an attorney, consistent with the Rules of Professional Conduct, purchase from an internet search engine company a keyword that is a competitor lawyer’s name in order to display the purchasing lawyer’s own website in the search results when a person searches for the competitor lawyer by name?

item.title: Kim Goulding v. NJ Friendship House, Inc.

Const. art. VIII, § 3, ¶¶ 2-3)?

State, 169 N.J. 422 (2001)?

item.description: Was the juvenile’s statement to his mother, which was overheard by a police officer before the juvenile was read his Miranda warnings, admissible at trial?

item.title: State in the Interest A.A.
item.description: Was the juvenile’s statement to his mother, which was overheard by a police officer before the juvenile was read his Miranda warnings, admissible at trial?

item.title: State v. Azmar Carter
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, was defendant entitled to suppress the evidence seized following his stop by four detectives who exited a vehicle, displayed badges, identified themselves as police, and instructed him to “stop”?

item.title: Christine Minsavage v. Board of Trustees, Teachers’ Pension and Annuity Fund
item.description: Is appellant entitled to survivor retirement benefits, rather than reimbursement of her husband’s pension contributions, under the circumstances presented?

item.title: Linda Cowley v. Virtua Health System
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, did the “common knowledge” exception apply to plaintiffs’ claims of medical malpractice, thereby relieving plaintiffs of their obligation to serve an affidavit of merit as required by the Affidavit of Merit Statute (AMS), N.J.S.A. 2A:53A-26 to -29.

item.title: Linda Cowley v. Virtua Health System
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, did the “common knowledge” exception apply to plaintiffs’ claims of medical malpractice, thereby relieving plaintiffs of their obligation to serve an affidavit of merit as required by the Affidavit of Merit Statute (AMS), N.J.S.A. 2A:53A-26 to -29.

item.title: Arthur G. Whelan v. Armstrong International, Inc.
item.description: In a products liability case arising out of exposure to asbestos, does a manufacturer have a duty to warn about the risk of harm from exposure to asbestos-containing replacement parts integral to the function of the manufacturer’s product, where the manufacturer did not fabricate or distribute the replacement parts?

item.title: Paul Barila v. Board of Education of Cliffside Park, Bergen County
item.description: Among other issues, do plaintiffs’ challenges to this negotiated collective bargaining agreement, which altered compensation for accumulated but unpaid sick leave, implicate a scope of negotiations issue such that defendant was entitled to dismissal of plaintiffs’ action?

item.title: In the Matter of Registrant G.H.; In the Matter of Registrant G.A.
item.description: In this appeal concerning the provisions of Megan’s Law, are defendants eligible for relief from their lifetime registration obligations, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 2C:7-2(f), or does subsection (g), which took effect in 2002, preclude their eligibility?

item.title: State v. Roger Covil
item.description: Among other issues, do the Court’s holdings in State v. Simms, 224 N.J. 393 (2016) and State v. Cain, 224 N.J. 410 (2016), concerning the permissible scope of expert testimony in drug cases, apply retroactively to cases in the pipeline; and may the State, in an ongoing criminal matter, use a defendant’s answer from a civil forfeiture matter when the defendant was not warned that the answer might be used in the criminal prosecution?

item.title: R.A. Feuer v. Merck & Co., Inc.
item.description: Was plaintiff, a shareholder, entitled to inspect certain corporate documents, pursuant to statute, N.J.S.A. 14A:5-28(4) (books and records; right of inspection), or the common law?

item.title: State v. Earnst Williams a/k/a Ernest Williams
item.description: In this matter where the victim was killed after meeting defendant to buy oxycodone pills, was defendant entitled to introduce evidence of the victim’s prior drug purchases?

item.title: S.L.W. v. N.J. Division of Pensions and Benefits
item.description: Did the Division of Pensions and Benefits err in interpreting N.J.A.C. 17:4-3.7 to require that this child claimant establish financial dependence on her retired parent by providing his income tax returns?

item.title: Sandra Woytas v. Greenwood Tree Experts, Inc.
item.description: Did the decedent, by committing suicide, breach the marital settlement agreement that required him to maintain life insurance?

item.title: Sergeant First Class Frank Chiofalo v. State of New Jersey
item.description: In this action alleging a violation of the New Jersey Conscientious Employee Protection Act, N.J.S.A. 34:19-1 to -8 (CEPA), was plaintiff required, as part of his prima facie case, to identify a specific law, regulation, or other authority that he reasonably believed had been violated?

item.title: State v. Susan Hyland
item.description: Does the Appellate Division have jurisdiction to consider the State’s appeal from defendant’s sentence to special Drug Court probation, N.J.S.A. 2C:35-14?

item.title: State v. A.T.C.
item.description: In this facial challenge to N.J.S.A. 2C:14-2(D), is the statute unconstitutional on the grounds that it violates the separation of powers doctrine? Did the State -- through the sentencing record and the Attorney General guidelines -- sufficiently explain its use of discretion to permit effective judicial review as required in State v. Vasquez, 129 N.J. 189 (1992), such that A.T.C.’s sentence did not violate the separation of powers doctrine?

item.title: Guerline Felix v. Brian V. Richards
item.description: Does N.J.S.A. 17:28-1.4, the Deemer statute, apply to an automobile insurance policy written in Florida for a Florida resident who had an accident in New Jersey, where the Florida policy did not include any bodily injury liability coverage?

item.title: G.A.-H. v. K.G.G.
item.description: Is an individual subject to tort liability for purportedly failing to warn a victim or alert authorities that a co-worker has engaged in the sexual abuse of a minor, under the circumstances presented?

item.title: Regina Little v. Kia Motors America, Inc.
item.description: In this class action concerning a front brake system that caused premature wear of the vehicles’ brake pads and rotors, was it error to award each member of the plaintiff class $750 ($6.3 million total) in repair damages?

item.title: State v. Luis Melendez
item.description: Among other issues, was it error to admit into evidence, defendant’s uncounseled answer in a parallel civil forfeiture case?

item.title: Moshe Meisels v. Fox Rothschild LLP
item.description: Can plaintiff maintain a cause of action for conversion and breach of fiduciary duty pertaining to $2.4 million deposited in the defendant law firm’s attorney trust account, under the circumstances presented?

item.title: State v. James Hemenway
item.description: Did the trial court err in denying defendant’s motion to suppress physical evidence seized from his apartment as well as statements defendant made to the police officers who arrested him where police officers entered defendant’s residence pursuant to a search warrant issued by the Family Part under the Prevention of Domestic Violence Act?

item.title: Bernice Pisack v. B&C Towing, Inc.; Eptisam Pellegrino v. Nick’s Towing Service, Inc.; Christopher Walker v. All Points Automotive & Towing, Inc.
item.description: In these cases involving the non-consensual towing of vehicles, several issues are raised concerning the Predatory Towing Prevention Act (Towing Act), N.J.S.A. 56:13-7 to -23 and its related regulations, the Consumer Fraud Act (CFA), N.J.S.A. 56:8-1 to -20, and the Truth-in-Consumer Contract, Warranty and Notice Act (TCCWNA), N.J.S.A. 56:12-14 to -18?

item.title: Donna Rowe v. Bell & Gossett Company
item.description: Did the trial court err in allowing a non-settling defendant (Universal) to introduce into evidence answers to interrogatories and deposition testimony from other defendants who had settled pretrial?

item.title: Gonzalo Chirino v. Proud 2 Haul, Inc., and Ivana Koprowski
item.description: Were defendants barred from challenging the amount of fuel tax damages awarded on partial summary judgment, where they raised the issue after the damages had been quantified and addressed by the trial court, and only on appeal?

item.title: State v. Isiah T. McNeal
item.description: Is defendant entitled to vacate his guilty plea based on his allegation that the trial court and counsel misinformed him with regard to the jail credits he would receive?

item.title: State v. Charudutt J. Patel
item.description: In this matter seeking post-conviction relief pursuant to State v. Laurick, 120 N.J. 1 (1990), was defendant required to show that, had he been notified of his right to counsel in a prior matter, the result of the proceeding likely would have been different?

item.title: T.L. v. Jack Goldberg, M.D.
item.description: In this medical malpractice action, did defense counsel’s failure to disclose that the defendant doctor’s trial testimony would differ from his interrogatory answers and deposition testimony result in plain error that required a new trial?

item.title: State v. Randy K. Manning
item.description: Were defendant’s cell phone records properly disclosed and admissible under the exigency exception?

item.title: State v. Noel E. Ferguson and Anthony M. Potts; State v. Shameik Byrd
item.description: Can defendants be prosecuted in New Jersey for the overdose death of the decedent under N.J.S.A. 2C:35-9(a) where the decedent purchased the CDS and died in New York?

item.title: State v. William T. Liepe
item.description: Did the consecutive sentences imposed on defendant as a result of his conviction for first-degree aggravated manslaughter and for second-degree aggravated assault, all arising from an automobile accident in which defendant was intoxicated, shock the judicial conscience and warrant resentencing?

item.title: J.H. and A.R. v. R&M Tagliareni, LLC
item.description: Did defendants, who owned and maintained a multi-family apartment building, owe a duty of care to the infant plaintiff, J.H., to protect him from the excessive heat of an uncovered radiator in one of the apartments?

item.title: State v. Joey J. Fowler and Jamil L. Hearns
item.description: Did the trial court’s failure to provide jury instructions on self-defense and lesser-included offenses require reversal of defendants’ convictions?

item.title: Janell Goffe v. Foulke Management Corp.; Sasha Robinson and Tijuana Johnson v. Mall Chevrolet
item.description: Were defendants entitled the dismissal of plaintiffs’ complaints based on the arbitration provisions of the sales contracts under the circumstances presented?

item.title: State v. Terrel L. Hyman
item.description: Did the officer’s affidavit establish probable cause to issue a search warrant for defendant’s home, where the affidavit did not include a reference to criminal activity conducted at or near defendant’s residence?

item.title: Garden State Check Cashing Service, Inc. v. State of New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, was New Loan Co., Wm. S. Rich & Son, Inc. exempt from the statute prohibiting a check cashing business from locating within 2,500 feet of another, N.J.S.A. 17:15A-41(e), by operation of the statute’s “Grandfather Clause,” N.J.S.A. 17:15A-50(a)?

item.title: State v. Rene M. Rodriguez
item.description: Can a defendant who is convicted of fourth-degree operating a motor vehicle during the period of license suspension in violation of N.J.S.A. 2C:40-26, serve the 180-day minimum sentence intermittently, or must the 180 days be served without interruption?

item.title: State v. Keith V. Cuff
item.description: Was defendant entitled to a new trial because of the omission on the verdict sheet of the charge of second-degree kidnapping, and did the trial court abuse its discretion by imposing consecutive sentences?

item.title: US Masters Residential Property (USA) Fund v. New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection
item.description: Among other issues, did claimant sustain its burden of showing that it was entitled to reimbursement under the New Jersey Spill Compensation and Control Act, N.J.S.A. 58:10-23.11 to -23.24?

item.title: State v. Rasul McNeil-Thomas
item.description: Among other issues, was defendant entitled to a new trial based on the prosecutor’s summation, which included the presentation of video surveillance footage and the prosecutor’s comments on that footage?

item.title: State v. A.M
item.description: Was defendant entitled to suppress his inculpatory statement under the circumstances presented, including the participation of a police officer serving, in part, as an interpreter of defendant’s interrogation?

item.title: Beryl Zimmerman and Judy Comment v. Sussex County Educational Services Commission
item.description: Did the defendant-employer violate the tenure rights of plaintiffs, part-time teachers, by substantially decreasing their work hours under the circumstances presented?

item.title: Patricia Engrassia v. Erick Uzcategui
item.description: Was plaintiff entitled to coverage under the dealer’s insurance policies for injuries sustained as a result of the defendant’s negligent operation of the dealer’s loaned vehicle?

item.title: State v. Rafael Camey
item.description: Was DNA evidence from defendant’s buccal swab admissible pursuant to the inevitable discovery doctrine?

item.title: In the Matter of Corey Corbo, Union City Police Department
item.description: Was there competent evidence adduced at the hearing to prove the police officer’s ingestion of cocaine and, if not, is the police department entitled to a remand to correct the evidentiary deficiencies?

item.title: Frank Caraballo v. City of Jersey City Police Department
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, can plaintiff maintain a claim of failure to accommodate under the Law Against Discrimination, N.J.S.A. 10:5-1 to -49, based on the denial of a benefit in a contemporaneous workers’ compensation matter?

item.title: Cynthia M. Blake v. Board of Review
item.description: Was claimant disqualified from obtaining unemployment benefits, pursuant to N.J.S.A. 43:21-5(a), as amended in 2015, where she resigned her job in order to accept a new position, but never commenced work in the new position because it was no longer available?

item.title: Frances Green v. Monmouth University
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, was Monmouth University, a non-profit educational institution, entitled to summary judgment on the ground of charitable immunity, where plaintiff allegedly was injured while attending a concert on University property?

item.title: L.R. v. Camden City Public School District
item.description: Are plaintiffs—the mother of a student with a disability and a nonprofit advocacy organization—entitled to obtain from several school districts redacted copies of settlement agreements and records reflecting the provision of special services to other qualified students?

item.title: State v. Dwight M. Nelson a/k/a Nelson Dwight
item.description: Under the circumstances presented, did the police have a reasonable articulable suspicion to stop defendant’s car; and were defendant’s rights violated when officers conducted a canine sniff during the course of the stop?

item.title: State v. L.H.
item.description: Was defendant’s statement to police obtained voluntarily where officers suggested that defendant would receive counseling and would not be jailed if he spoke with them; and, should one victim’s out-of-court identification have been suppressed for failure to comply with the recording requirements of Rule 3:11 and the principles established in State v. Delgado, 188 N.J. 48 (2006)?

item.title: State v. Davon M. Johnson
item.description: Did the State err in denying defendant’s application for admission into the Pretrial Intervention Program (PTI), based, in part, on its determination that defendant was presumptively ineligible for PTI because he was charged with third-degree possession of heroin with intent to distribute in a school zone?

item.title: State v. Kwesi Green
item.description: Is an out-of-court identification obtained using the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Area (HIDTA) system subject to the requirements of Rule 3:11, which governs the record of an out-of-court identification procedure?

item.title: Jennifer Kocanowski v. Township of Bridgewater
item.description: Is claimant, a volunteer firefighter, entitled to temporary disability payments for injuries that occurred when she was unemployed and therefore not earning a wage?

item.title: Patricia J. McClain v. Board of Review
item.description: Must an employee actually start new employment to be exempt from disqualification for unemployment benefits under N.J.S.A. 43:21-5(a), which exempts “an individual who voluntarily leaves work with one employer to accept from another employer employment which commences not more than seven days after the individual leaves . . . the first employer”?

item.title: Division of Child Protection and Permanency v. A.S.K., T.T., and E.M.C.
item.description: In this matter concerning the termination of E.M.C.’s parental rights to his son, did the Division prove the four prongs of the best interest test, N.J.S.A. 30:4C-15.1(a), under the circumstances presented?

item.title: Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada v. Wells Fargo Bank NA
item.description: Does a life insurance policy that is procured with the intent to benefit persons without an insurable interest in the life of the insured violate the public policy of New Jersey, and if so, is that policy void ab initio; and if such a policy is void ab initio, is a later purchaser of the policy, who was not involved in the illegal conduct, entitled to a refund of any premium payments that they made on the policy?
